column4: i'm not terribly familiar with linux file systems, can i move my home directory to another ext3 partition?
How do you mean?  You can create a new partition, and then mount it on /home.
Or you could change the path of your home directory, but I don't know why you would want to do that unless you have a lot of users.
OK, I've just read your previous comments as well, and it makes more sense now.
So, if I understand correctly, you have partitioned your disk to have 7G for the root partition, and then about 30G unused.  Is this correct?
OK, then you can create a new partition, copy the files from /home onto the new partition, empty /home and then mount the new partition on /home.
Unless you want to change the partitioning, you can just do (something like): sudo cp -a /home/* /media/hda2
This will depend on how the new partition is mounted.
Well, I think you can do that too, but I am an advocate of having a separate /home partition.  Having said that, I have found a bug in the gutsy installer that has problems with this.  :-(

The bug I found is this: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/migration-assistant/+bug/152261  You are only likely to see it, though, if you already have a separate /home partition from a previous install.
